Planning Security

The following is a list of questions that will help you plan security. For more information on the individual steps you need to perform to implement the level of security you select, see Setting Up Security.

  • What level of security do you need?

    • Can you use the same security definition for each project in a project database where all users have the same level of access to the archives? If so, then you can specify an access control database for the project database--none for the projects within the project database and no access lists. Then you can define all of the users that require access to the project database and define a custom privilege set or select a default privilege set for the users and assign it to each user. This level of security is further explained in security example 1.

    • Can you use the same security definition for each project in a project database? But, the users have different roles that they perform on the archives. If so, then you can define an access control database for the project database--none for the projects and no access lists. And, you can define privilege sets for each user role (or use the default privilege sets) and assign the appropriate privilege set to each user. This level of security is further explained in security example 2.

    • Do you need a different security definition for the archives in each individual project in a project database? If so, then you can define an access control database for each project but not define any access lists. This level of security is further explained in security example 3.

    • Do you need a different security definition for some archives of a project database? If so, then you must define an access list for those archives. This provides the greatest level of security. This level of security is further explained in security example 4.

  • Should you define access list groups to control archive access collectively? This should be done only if you are using access lists. We recommend that you use access list groups when defining access lists.
